Department of Chemistry King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals Dhahran Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are excellent for immobilizing guest active species due to their high surface area and porosity. In this study, CuO/UiO-66 catalysts with varying amounts of CuO were successfully synthesized and used for converting waste cooking oil (WCO) to biodiesel. The catalysts were characterized using N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, NH3-TPD, SEM, TEM, TGA and FTIR. The biodiesel was characterized using NMR and GC–MS. The results showed that CuO/UiO-66 displayed high catalytic activity due to the synergistic effect between UiO-66 and copper oxide in the composite. Under optimum reaction conditions, we achieved a 90.1 % conversion with the 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst. This catalyst also displayed good stability and reusability with a conversion of 81.06 % after three cycles. Our kinetic studies revealed a pseudo-first-order kinetics, with 32.26 kJ/mol in activation energy, consistent with a chemically controlled reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biodiesel Heterogeneous catalyst Free fatty acids UiO-66 MOF;CuO/UiO-66 catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The depletion of oil reserves, different environmental concerns and the increasing need for energy have prompted the quest for sustainable, environmentally benign alternative energy resources [1]. Biodiesel is considered an alternate fuel among several renewable energy sources that could effectively alleviate the environmental concerns about fossil fuel [2]. Furthermore, biodiesel has numerous benefits over fossil diesel fuel owing to its clean combustion, higher lubricity, biodegradability, nontoxicity, and renewability [2]. Biodiesel is produced by either esterification of free fatty acids (FFAs) or transesterification of triglycerides with methanol by using a suitable catalyst [3]. Biodiesel can be easily obtained from microalgae, animal fats, waste cooking oil (WCO) and vegetable oil [4]. For instance, edible oils like soybean, coconut, and sunflower have been extensively applied as biodiesel feedstock [5]. However, the high cost of these raw materials, as well as their use for food, hinders biodiesel production from them. Therefore, non-edible oils and WCO are favored as raw materials for biodiesel production due to their availability and low-cost [6–9]. Furthermore, using WCO will enhance economic benefits and solve the issues associated with its disposal. Biodiesel is typically formed using homogenous catalysts dissolved in alcohol [10,11]. Generally, homogeneous catalysts have the disadvantages of not being reusable and difficulty in separating the catalyst from products after the reaction. In addition, washing of biodiesel to remove dissolved impurities and catalyst residues generates huge amounts of wastewater [12]. These constraints with homogeneous catalysts can be circumvented using heterogeneous catalysts, which can be regenerated and recycled without losing activity [13]. Among the reported heterogeneous catalysts are carbon-based, sulfated zirconia, ion exchange resins, mixed metal oxides, transition metal oxides, heteropolyacids, zeolite, waste material based, Fe3O4@HKUST-1-ABILs and alkaline metal oxides catalysts [14–27]. However, in the instance of WCO having a significant quantity of FFAs, solid base catalysts react with these FFAs to produce soaps, giving rise to poor product quality [28]. In such instances, solid acid catalysts are preferred since they do not lead to saponification. However, the disadvantages of solid acid catalysts include lower conversion, low acidity, high cost, low thermal stability, and poor mass transfer. Previous studies showed that heteropolyacids could be used as Brønsted solid acid catalysts to produce biodiesel with high conversions [29,30]. Nevertheless, owing to their solubility in polar solvents, pure heteropolyacids are challenging to recover [31]. Transition metal oxides, including oxides of elements such as nickel, iron, copper, and cobalt, have been studied for their effectiveness in biodiesel production. Nevertheless, these catalysts face challenges like limited reusability, regeneration difficulties, and particle aggregation. In order to address these issues, incorporating support materials is crucial for enhancing active phase dispersion and stability. Supported solid acid catalysts have demonstrated excellent catalytic activities, making them more efficient in transforming WCO into biodiesel. Therefore, efforts have been directed towards utilizing effective supports such as MOFs, clays, silica, alumina and zeolite, to enhance the performance of these metal oxides [32–36]. Nonetheless, there is limited research on utilizing MOF-based catalysts specifically for transesterification of triglycerides for biodiesel production from WCO. MOFs have recently emerged as a novel class of materials with high surface area, controllable pore size, tunable composition, and flexibility [37,38]. Several features of MOFs have been employed in various sectors, including electronic, separations, optic, and catalysis [39]. Various MOFs, such as MIL-101, ZIF-8 and UiO-66 have recently been reported [39–46]. The yield of the hydrothermal synthesis method of UiO-66 at 120 °C after 6 h is 96 %. However, some MOFs, such as ZIF-8, quickly decompose in acidic environments, indicating that they are not resistant to acid medium [47]. In contrast, UiO-66 has shown excellent acid resistance (pH 2), high water resistance, relatively high chemical stability and high decomposition temperature due to the Zr's +4 oxidation state, allowing for 12 coordination and stabilizing the framework [42]. UiO-66 metal-organic framework has been employed to support photocatalysts for organic wastewater degrading applications [45,48]. UiO-66′s porous crystalline network has an imperfect framework with missing linkers, which induces active defects that aid substrate adsorption and reactant interactions [48]. Due to its reusability, thermal stability, and increased activity, UiO-66 is widely studied as a host matrix [48]. A previous report has presented the production of biodiesel utilizing UiO-66 catalyst [49]. For example, the activity of HSiW-UiO-66 catalysts in the production of biodiesel has been investigated, whereby an optimum biodiesel conversion of 80.5 % was obtained. Bravo Fuchineco et al. (2022) synthesized UiO-66(Zr) and UiO-66(Zr)-NH2 and used them as catalysts for the esterification of levulinic acid for obtaining biodiesel. Abou-Elyazed et al. synthesized a series of UiO-66(Zr)-structured materials with defects and used the resulting catalyst system for biodiesel production from oleic acid [50]. Li et al. prepared UiO-66 modified with ammonium sulfate by the impregnation technique and then used them as catalysts for the transesterification of oleic acid [51]. In a similar vein, Zhang and co-workers prepared a novel Ce-BDC@HSiW@UiO-66 composite synthesized by the simple solvothermal method. The resulting catalyst was used for the transesterification of oleic acid, giving a biodiesel conversion of 81.5 % [52]. Nonetheless, there is limited research on utilizing MOF-based catalysts specifically for transesterification of triglycerides for biodiesel production from WCO. To the best of our knowledge, we believe that there is no study on catalytic transesterification of triglycerides for biodiesel production from WCO utilizing CuO-impregnated Zr-based UiO-66 catalysts. In this work, we prepared a series of CuO-supported on UiO-66 (5–10 %CuO/UiO-66) as catalysts and utilized these catalysts to make biodiesel from WCO in the presence of methanol. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption, TGA, TEM, NH3-TPD SEM, XRD, and FTIR were used to characterize the resulting catalysts for textural properties, structural and chemical properties, and to correlate their structure with performance. Furthermore, the effect of various process parameters, including temperature, reaction time, molar ratio of methanol/WCO, and catalyst loading were studied to optimize the reaction. Finally, the reusability of the catalyst and reaction kinetics were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Waste cooking oil was obtained in-house from campus residence at KFUPM, and all chemicals were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Ethanol, methanol (purity >99 %), and N,N dimethylformamide (DMF > 99 %,) were procured from Sigma-Aldrich (USA). Terephthalic acid (AR), copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) and zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl4) were procured from Shanghai Aladdin Industrial Inc. Shanghai, China. 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst materials 2.2.1 UiO-66 synthesis The UiO-66 support was synthesized by the hydrothermal treatment method described by Zhang et al. [49]. Briefly, zirconium tetrachloride (0.51 g) was dissolved in DMF (18.0 ml) while stirring, then 0.3275 g of terephthalic acid was added. After 3 h of stirring, the sample was transferred to Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated hydrothermally for 6 h at 120 °C. Thereafter, the precipitate was obtained by centrifugation after cooling and the unreacted moieties were removed by repeatedly washing with DMF and ethanol. Afterwards, the wet solid sample obtained was oven-dried for about 12 hrs at 80 °C and this final sample is denoted as UiO-66. The final sample was then weighed to determine the yield of UiO-66, which was the percent of experimental UiO-66 yield to the theoretical UiO-66 yield based on the calculation of initial reagents. The hydrothermal synthesis method for UiO-66 gave a yield of 96 % at 120 °C after 6 h. 2.2.2 Catalysts synthesis We prepared CuO/UiO-66 catalysts by the method of wet impregnation. Briefly, in each case a pre-determined amount of copper nitrate trihydrate as a precursor for copper (corresponding to 5 %, 7 %, and 10 wt.% CuO loading) was dissolved in 15 ml of distilled water while stirring, and then 2.5 g of UiO-66 was added. After 3 h of stirring at 60 °C, the prepared materials were oven-dried at 120 °C in air for about 11 h. The catalysts developed were finally calcined for 4 h at 250 °C. So, the three catalysts synthesized were 5 %CuO/UiO-66, 7 %CuO/UiO-66, and 10 %CuO/UiO-66. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts The final catalyst materials were extensively characterized for structural, physical, and chemical properties. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the prepared materials were determined using a Porosity Analyzer (Micromeritic ASAP-2000) obtained from Micrometrics, USA. Prior to analysis, each catalyst sample was degassed in a vacuum-sealed tube at 120 °C for about 3 h. Using the BET technique, the specific surface areas of the catalysts were determined, and we used the Barret, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH) method to determine the pore size and pore volume distribution. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the materials was obtained with Bruker D2 Phaser 2nd Generation (Bruker, Karlsruhe, Germany) between 2θ = 5–80º with a resolution of 0.05° utilizing a Cu-Kα monochromatic radiation source of 0.15418 nm wavelength. The morphologies of the prepared materials were characterized using a Quattro scanning electron microscope (SEM), Thermo Fisher Scientific, Oxford Inc. UK. Before the SEM analysis, the catalysts were coated with gold films and put on carbon tape. Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) of the support and the catalysts were measured in air using a thermogravimetric analyzer (SDT Q600 instruments, USA) from 50 to 700 °C at the rate of 10 °C /min. We used Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 spectrometer, for FTIR characterization of the materials. The particle dispersion and size measurements were tested by transmission electron microscope JEOL-JEM-2100 TEM (JOEL Ltd. USA) operated at 200 kV. Before image analysis, we prepared the samples on carbon-coated grids, which was then placed on a sample holder, following which a high vacuum was applied. The acidity of the prepared samples was evaluated via temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) method, BELCAT-B, Microtrac, USA. with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, and the data were monitored from 100 to 420 °C. 2.4 Reaction procedure Typically, predetermined amounts of WCO, catalyst material, and methanol were added to a 50 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer and temperature controls (Parr stirred batch reactor, Parr Instrument Company, Moline, Illinois, USA). The reactants were agitated using a magnetically coupled mechanical stirrer at 400 rpm to maintain a uniform temperature and suspension. After each run, centrifugation was used to separate the catalyst from the reaction mixture, and a separating funnel was used to separate the resulting sample mixture of FAMEs-glycerol. The biodiesel phase was heated to 80 °C, which allowed the removal of any excess methanol. Thereafter, the biodiesel sample was cooled down to room temperature. 2.5 Determination of biodiesel conversion and composition Product composition was determined using GC-MS analysis (7890A GC, Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, USA). The measurement was carried out in split mode with an inlet temperature of 220 °C and helium flow rate of 1.2 mL/min. The oven was preheated at 200 °C and the solvent used was heptane. 1H and 13C NMR analyses of the biodiesel products were carried out in a Bruker NMR (Bruker Avance III, 400 MHz NMR Spectrometer, Bruker Corporation, Mundelein, Illinois, USA). We used 1H NMR for the determination of the% conversion of WCO to biodiesel. In a typical analysis, 0.05 g of the resulting biodiesel product was dissolved in 1 mL of CDCl3 solvent containing 0.05 % tetramethylsilane (TMS). Eq. (1) was employed to compute the% conversion [53]. (1) C ( % ) = [ ( 2 A ME ) / ( 3 A CH 2 ) ] × 100 where ACH2 is the integrated peak area of the methylene proton adjacent to the carbonyl (C=O) group; AME is the integrated peak area of the methoxy proton in the methyl ester, while C is the% of WCO converted to biodiesel. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the samples 3.1.1 XRD analysis Fig. 1 presents the XRD patterns of the UiO-66 support and the catalysts. It is clear that the UiO-66 is highly crystalline. The appearance of signature diffraction peaks at 2θ = 7.3 and 8.5° are indicative of the successful synthesis of UiO-66 and they confirm the crystallization of the UiO-66 framework [54]. The XRD pattern of the synthesized materials is consistent with previous reports [54]. The typical UiO-66 diffraction peaks at 6–8.5° are apparent following the copper oxide loading (5 %, 7 %, and 10 %, correspondingly) via impregnation, indicating that the preparation of the catalyst does not significantly affect the crystallinity of the UiO-66 support. Nevertheless, when the copper oxide loading increases, the UiO-66 diffraction peaks at 6–8.5° decreased. The decrease in peak intensities of UiO-66 upon loading CuO can likely be attributed to the formation of a composite material. The presence of CuO could induce subtle structural modifications and interactions within the UiO-66 framework, resulting in a reduction in peak intensities [37]. Additionally, interactions such as surface adsorption or chemical bonding between UiO-66 and CuO could further contribute to these observed changes [37]. We detected the characteristic diffraction peak of copper oxide phase on all CuO/UiO-66 catalysts, which appeared at 2θ = 38.7° and 68.1° representing (111) and (220) planes, correspondingly [38], and its intensity increases with increasing CuO loading. This indicates successful formation of copper oxide crystals [38]. 3.1.2 Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms studies Fig. 2 depicts the nitrogen-adsorption/desorption isotherms of the materials. The profile of the UiO-66 exhibits type I adsorption isotherm, indicating the presence of micropores. Despite the different loading of CuO, the profile of all the UiO-66-supported catalysts display type 1 isotherm, suggesting that the structure of UiO-66 support was preserved after catalyst loading. Table 1 shows the textual features of the prepared materials. The BET surface area of 1190 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.52 cm3/g of UiO-66 are consistent with literature reports [55]. The surface area of UiO-66 decreases after CuO loading due to blockage of the pores caused by deposition of CuO on the UiO-66 support. As the CuO loading increases from 5 % to 10 %, the surface areas of CuO/UiO-66 catalysts drop (Table 1 ). Also, the pore volume of UiO-66 decreases following the CuO loading, which suggests that the impregnation-reaction approach successfully introduces CuO into the UiO-66 framework. The pore size of UiO-66 was 4.07 nm. The pore size corresponds quite well to those reported in the literature [56–58]. We observed an increase in the pore size of the UiO-66 support after impregnation with CuO. This may be due to the fact that the cavities of the supporting UiO-66 are occupied by CuO [37]. 3.1.3 FTIR analyses FTIR spectra of the materials are depicted in Fig. 3 . For UiO-66 support, the C-O bonding in the carboxylates and C-C vibration modes are indicated by the peak at 1581 and 1395 cm−1, correspondingly. The Zr-(OC) asymmetric stretch is ascribed to the peak at 544 cm−1 [59]. The peaks around 741 and 671 cm−1, ascribed to the O-H and C-H vibrations in the BDC ligand, are consistent with previous reports [59]. The FTIR spectra of the CuO/UiO-66 catalyst systems are comparable to those of the Ui-O-66 support, suggesting that the impregnation of CuO species into UiO-66 support has no effect on the framework of the support. Comparatively, we found the stretching vibration peak at 1670 cm−1 for all the UiO-66-based catalysts used in this work, which corresponds to the Cu-O phase [60]. The fact that the FTIR spectra show the presence of Zr and CuO based on the above peak assignments suggest the CuO species are well incorporated into the UiO-66 support. 3.1.4 TGA characterization In order to determine the thermal stabilities of the materials, we conducted thermogravimetric measurements with the curves shown in Fig. 4 . At first, the initial mass loss occurring in the temperature range of 25−100 °C is attributed to physically adsorbed water, while the subsequent mass loss within the temperature range of 100−400 °C is ascribed to the removal of dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent. The weight loss found in the UiO-66 sample is in good agreement with previous reports [61,62]. The mass loss at 400–500 ºC is mostly due to the thermal decomposition of organic ligands [59,63]. As could be seen in Fig. 4, the decomposition of the organic linkers only started at high temperatures, thereby suggesting that the catalysts are thermally stable. Therefore, the results show that the synthesized catalysts have thermal stability and do not undergo structural collapse or lose their crystalline order when used for transesterification reactions around 140–200 ºC. 3.1.5 SEM and TEM measurements Fig. 5 presents the SEM images of the UiO-66 catalyst systems. SEM analysis revealed that UiO-66 exhibits uniform octahedral morphology (Fig. 5a). The morphology of the UiO-66 coincides with literature reports, where it was reported that UiO-66 has a uniform octahedral shape [64]. The crystals are uniformly dispersed, and the aggregated crystals are 100–200 nm in size (Fig. 5a). We observed that after copper oxide had been loaded onto UiO-66 (CuO/UiO-66), the shape of the particles remains essentially unchanged (Fig. 5b–d), thereby suggesting that CuO particles were distributed uniformly on the UiO-66 support. Fig. S1 (Supporting Information) illustrates the EDX analysis and mapping images of UiO-66 MOF and CuO/UiO-66 catalysts. In the EDX analysis, peaks corresponding to Zr and Cu are evident for samples, while the mapping confirms the uniform dispersion of CuO in the UiO-66 support. The EDX mapping confirms the uniform dispersion of CuO in the UiO-66 support. TEM was utilized to determine the particle dispersion and size distribution of the catalyst materials. TEM images of CuO/UiO-66 catalyst systems are presented in Fig. 5e–g. As shown, the images indicate that the CuO particles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of UiO-66. Selected area electron diffraction of the TEM images (Fig. 5e–g inset) supported the uniform distribution of CuO over UiO-66. The histograms in the inset of Fig. 5e–g suggest an estimated particle size of CuO in the range of 2.5–16 nm, and the average particle size for 5 %CuO/UiO-66, 7 %CuO/UiO-66 and 10 %CuO/UiO-66 were 7.69 nm, 6.44 nm and 6.89 nm, respectively. Considering CuO was loaded onto UiO-66 via the impregnation method, it's plausible that at higher loadings, the distribution of CuO within the UiO-66 matrix becomes more uniform. This uniform distribution may lead to the formation of smaller CuO nanoparticles or clusters within the pores of the UiO-66 framework. Consequently, this phenomenon could contribute to the observed decrease in CuO particle size with increasing loading. The CuO particles were larger than the average pore size of UiO-66 (4.07 nm according to BET analyses); thus, a substantial amount of CuO was deposited on the surface of UiO-66. Moreover, the arrangement of CuO on the UiO-66 without particle agglomeration suggests adequate dispersion of CuO over the UiO-66 support. 3.1.6 NH3-TPD analysis NH3-TPD was used to determine the acidity of the prepared materials, and the results are presented in Fig. 6 and Table 1. According to Fig.6, NH3-TPD measurement shows that all samples exhibit a pronounced desorption peak between 110 and 420 °C, indicating the desorption of ammonia from acid sites. UiO-66 acidity originates from Lewis acidic Zr sites (Zr-OH) and defect generated in Zr6 clusters due to missing organic linkers [65–67]. The acidity of CuO/UiO-66 increases following CuO loading compared to UiO-66 because of the missing linker and the presence of a coordinated free carboxylate group. The integrated peak areas increases with the increase in CuO loading, suggesting an increase in the acid sites after copper exchange [67]. As shown, the acid sites steadily increased with the catalyst loaded (Table 1 ). 3.2 Investigations about the catalysis process 3.2.1 Catalyst selection for biodiesel production The performance of the prepared materials for WCO methanolysis to produce biodiesel was investigated. The activity of the catalyst materials was investigated at fixed process parameters (catalyst loading of 4 wt% and 16:1 methanol/WCO ratio for 2 h at 150 °C). Fig. 7 depicts the biodiesel conversion using several synthesized catalysts. As shown, the biodiesel conversion of CuO/UiO-66 catalysts were significantly increased in comparison with that of the UiO-66. This increase in activity may be ascribed to the large pore size and the synergistic effect between UiO-66 and copper oxide composite. These pores trap the substrate and move it closer to the catalyst system's active site since they are considerably larger than triglyceride molecules. Also, the synergistic effect between UiO-66 and copper oxide composite enhanced the adsorption of bulky triglycerides to reach the active sites and provide sufficient active sites for transesterification reaction, which favored the conversion of bulky triglycerides molecules into biodiesel molecules. Further increasing the CuO loading in the UiO-66 support increases the active CuO sites, which results in higher WCO biodiesel conversion by 7 %CuO/UiO-66 compared to 5 %CuO/UiO-66 (Fig. 7). However, further increasing the CuO incorporated into the UiO-66 framework may block the pores and lead to a higher diffusion resistance during the mass transfer reactions, which can reduce the number of accessible active sites. This is the case with 10 %CuO/UiO-66, which shows a lower biodiesel conversion than that with CuO loading of 7 % (7 %CuO/UiO-66). Among all the catalysts, 7 %CuO/UiO-66 shows the highest biodiesel conversion. Therefore, it is concluded that the optimum CuO loading is 7 % for this transesterification reaction. Also, in order to avoid CuO agglomeration on the surface of the UiO-66 support and to conserve raw materials, we utilized this 7 %CuO/UiO-66 as the solid acid catalyst for further investigation. 3.3 Effects of different reaction conditions 3.3.1 Temperature and reaction time Reaction temperature is one of the most crucial parameters to optimize in biodiesel synthesis because it profoundly influences the reaction rate. To investigate how the reaction temperature influences the biodiesel conversion, some experiments were carried out using 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst (catalyst loading of 6 wt%) at 140, 150, 160, and 170 °C with molar ratio of 20:1 at 4 h reaction time (Fig. 8 a). The results revealed that at higher temperatures, biodiesel conversion increases, with an optimal conversion of 90.10 % for the 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst at 160 °C. The mass transfer rate between the catalyst, oil, and methanol increased at higher temperatures since the reactants acquired enough kinetic energy, which results in maximum biodiesel conversion. At a temperature higher than 160 °C, the WCO conversion started to decrease marginally. The optimal temperature for the process is therefore taken as 160 °C. The effect of reaction time on WCO conversion to biodiesel was evaluated at 160 °C with a 6 wt% catalyst loading and molar ratio of 20:1 (Fig. 8b). The result shows that the catalyst was incompletely activated during the first hour, which resulted in a low biodiesel conversion due to low reaction rate. Nevertheless, the conversion increased progressively as the reaction time increased and reached 90.09 % in 4 h. At reaction times longer than 4 h, biodiesel conversion reduced, apparently due to reverse reaction that occurs between glycerol and FAME as reaction time increases. Therefore, 4 h is considered as the optimal reaction time for this catalyst system (7 %CuO/UiO-66). 3.3.2 Effects of catalyst loading and methanol to oil molar ratio Catalyst loading can have a profound influence on WCO conversion to biodiesel. So, we examined the effect of this parameter on biodiesel synthesis by varying the catalyst loading from 2 wt% to 8 wt% with molar ratio of 20:1 at 160 °C for 4 h. As shown in Fig. 9 a, biodiesel conversion steadily increased and reached a maximum of 90.08 % on increasing the catalyst loading from 2 wt% to 6 wt%. However, beyond the loading of 6 wt%, the biodiesel conversion declines, presumably due to a restricted mixing because of the presence of the solid catalyst, reactants, and products [68–71]. Also, biodiesel conversion may drop because of the higher adsorption of biodiesel products onto the catalyst surface as the amount of catalyst increases above the optimal level [72]. Therefore, 6 wt% catalyst loading was used to optimize other reaction parameters. Fig. 9b depicts the influence of methanol loading on WCO biodiesel production using 7 %CuO/UiO-66 (6 wt% catalyst loading) at 160 °C in over 4 h. We observed that increasing the methanol/WCO ratio led to increased biodiesel conversion. On increasing the ratio to 20:1, the biodiesel conversion increased to 90.10 %. Nevertheless, beyond the ratio of 20:1, biodiesel conversion decreased. The higher molar ratio might lead to an incomplete reaction, with the presence of monoglycerides and diglycerides as byproducts [73]. So, in this study, we conclude that the 20:1 methanol/WCO ratio is sufficient to produce biodiesel from WCO. 3.4 Biodiesel characterization 3.4.1 1H NMR analyses Fig. S2 (a & b) shows the 1H NMR of WCO and biodiesel, correspondingly. As depicted in Fig. S2 (a), the 1H NMR of WCO revealed triglyceride peaks with olefinic protons at 5.37 ppm and glyceridic backbone signals at 4.17- 4.32 ppm. The disappearance of glyceridic backbone signals between 4.17- 4.32 ppm and the appearance of a triplet signal related to alpha-CH2 proton at 2.32 ppm and a single peak corresponding to methoxy protons at 3.67 ppm confirm the formation of biodiesel product [Fig. S1 (b)]. Other signals observed include those at 1.60, 1.25, and 0.89 ppm for beta-carbonyl methylene protons, carbon methylene protons and terminal methyl protons, respectively, which are consistent with literature reports [74,75]. The signals at 5.36 ppm are related to olefinic hydrogens [74–76]. 3.4.2 13C NMR analysis The 13C NMR of WCO and biodiesel is shown in Figure S3 (a & b). The signals at 68.88 and 62.09 ppm are ascribed to -O-CH- and -O-CH2- groups in WCO, respectively [Fig. S3 (a)]. These signals disappear with the formation of methyl esters, and a new signal associated with –OCH3 carbon appears around 51.42 ppm [Fig. S3 (b)]. The carbonyl of ester in WCO produces a peak at 173.24 ppm. Unsaturated fatty acids can be seen at 127.90 and 130.19 ppm in 13C NMR spectra of biodiesel, and ester carbonyl is shown at 174.31 ppm. Signals between 22 and 34 ppm are attributed to the -CH2-CH2, while another peak at 14.11 ppm is due to the methyl group's end-chain carbon of FAME [75,77]. Table S1 also presents the fuel properties of the as-produced biodiesel in conjunction with ASTM standards. The fuel properties of the biodiesel product with the 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst conform to the ASTM D6751 standard, suggesting that the biodiesel product is usable either as a neat fuel or may be used as a blend consisting of petroleum diesel. The composition of biodiesel product was further examined using the GC-MS technique to identify the various esters that are present in FAME product. Fig. S4 presents the GC-MS chromatogram while Table S2 shows the components of the biodiesel product. 3.5 Kinetic studies Independent experiments were conducted under the optimum WCO conversion conditions for the kinetic study: methanol/WCO ratio of 20:1, 6 wt% catalyst loading, 4 h reaction time and reaction temperature was varied in each experiment (140 °C, 150 °C, 160 °C). In general, three sequential reversible reaction steps occur during transesterification reaction (Fig. 10 ). First, diglyceride is formed through the conversion of triglyceride to diglyceride. In the second step, diglyceride is then converted to monoglyceride. The process of converting monoglyceride to glycerol then follows. At each step of the reaction, a FAME is formed. Therefore, the method produces a total of three FAMEs. Since methanol was employed in excess, the reverse reaction may be ignored, and the reaction is believed to be governed by the pseudo-first-order model [78,79]. Thus, Eq. (2) fits the reaction rate constant [78], and the activation energy (Ea ) needed for the reaction is computed using the Arrhenius equation 3 [78]. (2) k = − In 1 − X t (3) In k = In A − E a R T where A = frequency of collision; k = reaction rate constant; X = WCO conversion at time t; T = reaction temprature (Kelvin); R = (8.314 J mol−1 K −1). The plot of -ln (1- X ) vs. time is presented in Figure S5 (a). Linear regression was used to obtain the k at different temperatures, and it was found that k increases with increasing reaction temperature. Due to resultant improved mass transfer, raising the temperature increases the rate of the reaction. The Ea of the reaction was calculated to be 32.26 kJ/mol using the plot of ln k against 1/T (Fig. S5 (b). It has been reported that chemically controlled reactions typically have Ea values higher than 25.0 kJ/mol, while diffusion-limited reactions have a lower Ea (10 to 15 kJ/mol) [80–83]. So, the Ea of the reaction can be used as an indicator of whether the transesterification reaction under study is controlled by the chemical step or mass transfer/diffusion-limited. Therefore, our experimental findings here show that the transesterification of WCO is chemically-controlled in the present study given the high Ea of 32.26 kJ/mol. We wish to mention that in order to mitigate internal diffusion limitations, we have carefully selected appropriate catalyst materials and particle sizes to facilitate efficient diffusion of reactants to active sites, thus reducing internal mass transfer resistances. With regards to external diffusion limitations, we have taken proactive measures to minimize their impact on our kinetics study. We have employed stirring agitation to maintain uniform concentration gradients within the reaction mixture, thereby reducing the occurrence of external diffusion limitations. Furthermore, we have optimized process parameters such as temperature to promote faster diffusion rates and mitigate any external mass transfer resistances. 3.6 Proposed reaction mechanism The synthesis of biodiesel from WCO may be illustrated with a plausible mechanism via transesterification/esterification reactions (Fig. 11 ). The fatty acid and triglyceride species that are present in the WCO bind to the CuO/UiO-66 catalyst to produce the protonated carbonyl group, which is then attacked by the nucleophilic oxygen atom from methanol's hydroxyl group to form a tetrahedral intermediate (the nucleophilic oxygen atom from methanol hydroxyl group attacks the electrophilic carbon in the fatty acid/triglycerides) [66]. Glycerol is a byproduct produced in the transesterification pathway in FAME synthesis, while a water molecule is produced in the esterification pathway. FAMEs are desorbed from the catalyst surface through electron delocalization at the oxygen atom. After regeneration, the catalyst can be utilized for another catalytic cycle. 3.7 Reusability of catalysts The heterogeneous solid catalysts reusability test is important because it demonstrates the benefit of utilizing a catalyst to lower the preparation cost for industrial use. In order to evaluate the catalyst reusability in the present study, the 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst was centrifuged after each cycle (Centrifuge 5420, Eppendorf, USA), oven-dried at 100 °C for 8 h after being washed with methanol, and then used for the next cycle. Under the optimal reaction condition (6 wt% catalyst and 20:1 methanol/WCO at 160 °C for 4 h), the reaction was repeated six times, and the findings are presented in Fig. 12 . We found that even after three reuses, the catalyst activity could maintain a conversion of more than 80 %. This result suggests that incorporating CuO into the UiO-66 cavities enhanced the activity and WCO conversion, while preserving the stability of the catalyst. In order to get a fairly accurate idea about the stability of the catalyst, XRD analysis was performed, and the results are presented in Fig. S6. Based on this figure, the recycled catalyst was substantially comparable to that of the unspent (fresh) catalyst, albeit an observed reduction in peak intensity, which indicates that the structure and composition of the 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst were largely preserved. However, the slight drop in activity is likely owing to leaching of the active component of the catalyst into the reaction medium. Based on the analysis above, the synthesized 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst exhibits good stability in biodiesel production. Table 2 presents a comparison of the performance of different solid catalysts that are used in biodiesel production using low-grade oil/oleic acid as the feedstock. Interestingly, when WCO was used as a feedstock, the performance of the catalysts reported in this work is comparable to other studies. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, CuO/UiO-66 catalysts prepared through a wet impregnation method are effective catalyst systems in the synthesis of biodiesel from WCO. The as-prepared CuO/UiO-66 catalyst systems present high catalytic activity. This is because of the appropriate pore size, large surface area and the synergistic effect between UiO-66 and copper oxide composite. The catalyst with a CuO of 7 wt.% (7 %CuO/UiO-66) exhibited a high conversion of 90.10 % under the optimum process conditions of 6 wt% catalyst loading and 20:1 molar ratio at 160 °C for 4 h. Based on a kinetic investigation that revealed the reaction followed pseudo-first-kinetics, we estimated the activation energy to be 32.26 kJ/mol. Our kinetic studies reveal that the esterification/transesterification reaction is chemically controlled as against diffusion and mass transfer constraints. In addition, the 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst showed good stability, and the WCO conversion was still more than 80 % after three cycles of use. Therefore, the presented 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst is potentially useable in an industrial setting for biodiesel production given that it is recyclable and can convert cheap feedstocks such as WCO into biodiesel. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are excellent for immobilizing guest active species due to their high surface area and porosity. In this study, CuO/UiO-66 catalysts with varying amounts of CuO were successfully synthesized and used for converting waste cooking oil (WCO) to biodiesel. The catalysts were characterized using N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, NH3-TPD, SEM, TEM, TGA and FTIR. The biodiesel was characterized using NMR and GC–MS. The results showed that CuO/UiO-66 displayed high catalytic activity due to the synergistic effect between UiO-66 and copper oxide in the composite. Under optimum reaction conditions, we achieved a 90.1 % conversion with the 7 %CuO/UiO-66 catalyst. This catalyst also displayed good stability and reusability with a conversion of 81.06 % after three cycles. Our kinetic studies revealed a pseudo-first-order kinetics, with 32.26 kJ/mol in activation energy, consistent with a chemically controlled reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and evaluation of CuO/UiO-66 metal-organic frameworks as a solid catalyst for biodiesel production from waste cooking oil
